A user reports:

When attempting to add a CVS module, I get the following error:

Error parsing cvs log: RCS filename 'c:\cvs\welfare\ant/.classpath,v' does not start with the provided root 'c:\cvs\welfare/ant'

Note the slashes separating "c:\cvs\welfare" (our CVS repository path) and "ant" (the module name). The CVS log contains back slashes (\) while the "provided root" contains a forward slash \(/).

I confirmed that the log file contains back slashes. A command line cvs log command reports backslashes.

The slash in the "provided root" is (I believe) put there by Jira. When entering the details in the "Add CVS module" screen, the "CVS Root" and "Module Name" are entered separately.

Is there a parameter somewhere which tells Jira that we are using CVS/CVSNT on Windows (ie use back slashes) rather than CVS on Unix/Linux (ie use forward slashes). Jira has to match what CVS reports, so Jira needs to know how CVS is reporting the file names. An alternative would be to use slash-independent string comparison,
fields.summary: Error parsing CVS log: wrong slash when using CVSNT

  {panel}

We're using a Non Quoted Comment Handler to add comments to issues via email. Some of our emails to JIRA users have bounced, leaving bounce messages from "System Administrator" in the mailbox. These messages cause the handler to write warnings to the stdout log. Over time, as these messages pile up in the mailbox, these log entries cause the log to ballon to 100mb+, which eventually results in the JIRA service throwing Out of Memory exceptions. I can imagine this would only be worse if say, virus infected clients were sending messages to the JIRA mailbox in question.

Possible solution:
+ Add an option to the handler "Delete messages from unauthorized mail senders"
+ Add a sub-option: "Log message body before deletion"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-5496].
  {panel}

Within a workflow it is possible to assign an issue to a particular user (person), by specifying a Post Function 'Update Issue Field' for the 'Assign To' field, or by using the Post Function 'Assign to Reporter'. What is missing is a means to (re)assign the issue automatically.

Consider the workflow we need in our organisation:

1) Create Issue
2) Open
3) Resolve (Incomplete)
   - Assign To Reporter
4) Reopen Issue / Clarified
   - Assign to Original Assignee / Assign Automatic
5) Open
....

The issue is opened normally. In step 3 the assignee discovers that the issue is incomplete, and Resolves the bug as Inclomplete. Now, the Post Function 'Assign to Reporter' takes care of assigning the bug to the reporter. The Reporter should now be able to add information that will make the issue complete, and Reopen the bug (or use some custom WF action, e.g. 'Clarified'). This should assign the issue to the orginal assignee automatically (throug a Post Function).

The reason this functionality is needed is that we do not want to give all reporters full assign rights, but want to be able to return an issue to a reporter.

A new Post Function should be implemented that is equivalent to the Automatic assign that is used when an issue is created, or a fucntion that assigns it to the previous assignee (the one that sent it back to the reporter, in our example)
fields.summary: Assign to first or last assignee workflow post-function

We are using an external tool to develop JIRA reports.
This tool connects directly to the database to generate reports.
It works fine except for reports that are using rules based on the history of changes.
In fact, the way you are storing changes in the changeitem table is not suitable and not generic enough.
You are storing only strings.

2 examples :

- Regarding the way you are qtoring dates: you are storing them using the screen format. If this format changes during the life of JIRA, we will have several date formats in the history. Then, it's very difficul for our reporting tool to analyse the dates and make differences...
- Regarding the custom fields:
   - you are storing the values as string.
   - You are storing only the name of the custom fields and not their ID. So, if the name changes, the external reporting tool will be unable to get the history of this field.

So, you should change the way you are storing changes by :
- storing old values and new values like the CUSTOMFIELDVALUE does
- storing the ID of custom fields and not only the name.

Today, we can answer to the need of users that want to have complex reports, but we know that if some custom field names change, the reports won't work anymore...

Do you think you could change this in a future version ?
fields.summary: Changes are not stored in a proper way

So what would be cool for large installations would be a vacation plugin.  A user, say Alice, tells Jira that she'll be gone from Date X to Date Y.  Jira then presents Alice with a list of all the Projects and Components and other pre-set assignments that she is configured for.  Alice can then individually or in batch (checkboxes or whatever) select another Jira user or users to have newly created issues assigned to them while she's away.  In fact, the email template for vacation issue creation may even be different.  E.g.  JiraBob, you've been assigned this issue (yadahdhdhdha) b/c Alice is away on vacation from X to Y.  (if the current date is close enough to y, JiraBob may choose to ignore it :)

What do you think?  Or is this functionality there already in a way that I'm not aware of?  This would really help us in that issues wouldn't a. fall thru cracks and b. when getting back from vacation (yes, sometimes we take vacation) we don't have a pile of issues waiting for us.

I'm willing to start and tackle this as a plugin.  I don't have a source/commercial license.  Can I build this plugin without the source, just using the API and Jira blogs/email lists?  I don't want to go down the road if I'm not goign to be able to finish it.

(i) This plugin can be used [Out Of Office Assistant|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.akelesconsulting.jira.plugins.OutOfOfficeAssistant/server/overview], Please contact the plugin vendor in order to make sure about functionality as Atlassian does not support third party plugins.

I have a customised Jira/Confluence installation.

In our installation, we do not want to have a central administrator. Therefore we allow any user to create:

* groups of users (users are authenticated using LDAP and I have arranged that user profiles are created upon authentication if they do not exist so no need to create user accounts manually)
* projects
* permission schemes
* notification schemes
* workflows

etc. etc.

It would be ideal if all these entities had ACLs associated with them. In particular user groups really should not be modifiable by anyone - if we protect content in Confluence by granting permission to a particular group, we really don't want people to be able to view the content by going in and temporarily adding themselves to the appropriate group.

The ACLs should allow specification of users and groups for read, update and delete operations.

*Original request description:*
 
As JIRA user who creates issues and subtasks I want this process to be as easy as possible. Therefore I want the subtasks to assume the values of fields from the parent issue, so that I do not have to enter these values manually. But at the same time I want to be provided with a choice of the fields which will be used for propagation, because clearing redundant fields is going to also cost me some time. Among the propagated fields the following should be allowed for selection as a minimum: affected version, fix version, components and optionally: severity and labels.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-5202].
  {panel}

Currently in JIRA, an issue is deemed resolved (in reports, portlets etc) if it has a resolution set.  This includes both Resolved and Closed issues, and generally works fine.  However in JIRA 3, people can:

 - Have more than one issue deemed 'closed', but which may not yet have a resolution
 - Edit the 'resolve' transition (or equivalent) to not set the resolution

In these cases, the built-in assumption that resolution == closed breaks.  It would be better to just have a 'closed' flag on the issue.  This would also enable a number of new queries and statistics to be generated (ask Mike for details).

I'm adding new statuses to JIRA in order to match our workflow. For example, I have "New" status (which will precede the "Open" status). 

However, if I order issues in JIRA by their status, issues are ordered as "Open" > "New" > "In Progress" > "Resolved" 

I'd need to be able to specify the order ("New" > "Open" > "In Progress" > "Resolved") for the status field (same way as priorities, resolutions and issue types can be ordered)

Note: Workaround from the comments also documented in [How to re-order statuses|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/How+to+re-order+statuses]. This workaround does not apply to OnDemand customers.

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 20 February 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thank you for your feedback. The JIRA product management team is working to make jira.atlassian.com a more valuable service by ensuring it accurately reflects the relative prioritization of feature requests. Remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of the many sources of feedback we use when planning the JIRA roadmap. For more details, [please read our post on the subject|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

With that said, we have chosen to close this issue. While we recognize that it would be valuable in a number of use cases, we have not been able to prioritize this issue for the past 10 years and do not expect this to change in the foreseeable future.

There are a number of ways to achieve recurring issues in JIRA:
* [TheScheduler|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/pl.com.tt.jira.plugin.theschedulerpro], available for JIRA Server.
* [Recurring Tasks|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.gebsun.atlassian.rtasks], available for JIRA Cloud.
* Simply clone issues issues prior to closing them. You can also automate this with the [Create Issue on Transition add-on|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/org.swift.jira.cot].
* Use any kind of scripting tool, like a Cron job, and create issues via the [JIRA REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/jiradev/api-reference].
* There are a number of discussions of different strategies on Atlassian Answers [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/80032/recurring-jira-issues], [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/69329/periodic-tasks-in-jira?page=1#69368], [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/66154/how-do-you-automatically-set-recurring-issues], and [here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/75358/recurring-issues].

I recognize that this may come as disappointing news. Please remember that our goal is to make jira.atlassian.com more useful to you by ensuring that the every open suggestion is something we truly plan to implement.

As always, please do not hesitate to contact me with questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
Product Manager, JIRA Platform

At various points in JIRA, one chooses a recipient for some form of email notification:

 - Notification schemes
 - Watchers
 - Filter subscriptions

Currently only individuals can 'watch' an issue, and only individuals or groups can subscribe to a filter.  It would be nice if one could choose any valid recipient (reporter, assignee, random email, single user) for each of these.  This might involve extracting out common code into a Recipients object.

When 2 users try working on same issue at same time one of the users who is trying to modify a stale version of issue will get a very ugly error screen with no clear indication of the cause of the error.

use case:
(assume both users have permission to modify X-1)

0. issue X-1 is in Open state
1. user1 opens issue X-1
2. user2 opens issue X-1
3. user1 updates X-1 by clicking on Start Progress action
4. user2 is not aware of user1 clicking Start Progress, user2 has not reloaded the web page view of X-1, so the issue still appears as Open. user2 tries to start progress also.
At this point user2 gets ugly error screen.
Instead user2 should get a polite message informing him/her that the issue has been modified by another person and that it should be reloaded in the browser before proceeding with changes.

Raised for Kyle Lucas (JSP-265):

"It is kind of ugly to have to do a filter every time I want to look for
a value in custom field. So for example if I want to find my custom
field called companyname(my custom field). I have to create a filter
for companyname equal to the value I want and run it- every time. Is
there a way to just type in the custom field somewhere and have it
happen? Like in quick search. Or even better yet. A way to specifiy

- 14 and the status = OPEN and the "custom field=X:prompt" the user

Kyle "
